title: Hyperbolic Geometry in Desmos
text: These are models of two-dimensional hyperbolic geometry, implemented in desmos. Click & drag points to see how the lines change.

title: Hyperbolic Geometry in Desmos
section: lines in the Poincare half plane
text:
lines in the Poincare half plane
P and Q are points in the upper half plane model of hyperbolic geometry. The orange curve is the hyperbolic line through P and Q.
 [link]

title: Hyperbolic Geometry in Desmos
section: lines in the Poincare disc model
text:
lines in the Poincare disc model
The pink region represents the Poincare disc model of hyperbolic geometry.
Choose a line and two points not on it. Drag the two points on top of each other. Notice you can draw multiple lines through the points and neither intersects the given line.
 [link]

title: Hyperbolic Geometry in Desmos
text:
area of hyperbolic triangles
Notice the area of a hyperbolic triangle is determined by its angle sum. Drag the vertices of the triangle to see how the area changes as the angle sum changes.
 [link]

title: Josh Thompson’s research
text: I am interested in geometry and topology and their applications to data analysis, computer vision, and machine learning. I also enjoy mentoring undergraduate research projects in these areas. Below are links to some of my work, software, and resources for students interested in pursuing research in these areas.

title: Basis element for the induced topology on a genus two surface
text:
A genus two surface embedded in Euclidean space, shown below embedded in \(\mathbb{R}^3\) \[\Sigma_2 \subset \mathbb{R}^3\] inherits a topology whose basis elemnts are intersections of the surface with open balls \[\mathcal{B}_i = \Sigma_2 \cap B(\epsilon).\] A random such intersection is shown below on the left. The animation on the right shows three different basis elements.
